snippet: The average price for a Manhattan apartment rose 20 percent to $1,697,000 in the second quarter, compared with the same period last year, according to a report.
abstract: Corcoran Group report shows that after two-year shortage of apartments for sale, inventory in Manhattan is inching up again, but there are still too few apartments to go around; average price for Manhattan apartment rose 20 percent to $1,697,000 in second quarter, compared with same period last year; median price, which measures middle of market and is less affected by high-end sales, was up 6 percent to $920,000.
lead_paragraph: The average price for a Manhattan apartment rose 20 percent to $1,697,000 in the second quarter, compared with the same period last year, according to a report.

headline.main: Apartment Inventory Is Up in Manhattan; Prices Are, Too
headline.print_headline: Apartment Inventory Is Up; Prices Are, Too
